Iâ€™ve seen people cry after a rejection.
Not because they didnâ€™t get the jobâ€¦
But because the process broke them.

â€“ Ghosted after 6 rounds.
â€“ No feedback after weeks of effort.
â€“ False promises about salary, role, and growth.

Because behind every application is a story:
â€“ A fresh graduate supporting their family.

â€“ A parent who just wants stability for their kids.

A simple â€˜Thank you, we appreciate your timeâ€™ can bring hope.

Bhai, ninja bhi Zomato join kar le isse acha.

You didnâ€™t get rejected because youâ€™re not good enough.

You didnâ€™t get that â€œWeâ€™ll get back to youâ€ mail because you lacked effort.

The truth is:

* Many job postings already have someone in mind.

* Many â€œrecruitment processesâ€ are designed to exploit hope, not talent.

But hereâ€™s what they canâ€™t take away from you:
âœ” Your skills that youâ€™ve built brick by brick.
âœ” Your resilience that kept you going despite rejections.
âœ” Your fire to grow, even when the world is unfair.

To every job seeker reading this:

Please spend 1 minute to read this post - 

My trust in humanity has sunk deeper today.

Just saw someone's post that they have been posting for the last 2 years.

They post the same thing every 3â€“5 days â€“
"A humble request â€“ I am jobless..."

Each post gets 8000+ likes and 500+ comments.

Many people in the comments said they reached out with opportunities, but he never replied.

Because the numbers never added - 2 years ago he posted that I have been jobless for 3 years, this year he posted 2 years etc.

Even I asked him, let me mentor you free. I sent him some job postings. No reply. Nothing.

That person now has 25k+ followers and is doing paid sponsorships.

The cry for help is no longer a cry for survival.
It has become a strategy for attention.

And this is heartbreaking.

Because every time someone fakes struggle for reach, the ones genuinely struggling lose trust.
The people who really need jobsâ€¦ end up being ignored.
The kindness of strangers gets exploited.
The community becomes numb to real pain.

If youâ€™re ever tempted to â€œgameâ€ vulnerability â€“
please remember:
Your temporary clout is costing someone else their opportunity to survive.

Not everything is content.
Some things are sacred.
And the pain of survival should never be a marketing tool.

Next time, please check the profile of people - this person came out as a con artist.

I didnâ€™t get rejected from a company.
I got rejected by 57 companies.

Not in one year.
In a single day.

Some never replied.
Some ghosted after 5 rounds.
Some said, â€œWeâ€™re looking for someone with more stability.â€
Some just stopped posting the job after interviews.

At first, I thought: Maybe Iâ€™m not good enough.
But then I realized - this wasnâ€™t a reflection of my skills.
It was a reflection of a broken hiring system.

Because talent doesnâ€™t vanish with one rejection.
Potential doesnâ€™t expire because of HR silence.
And your worth is not defined by an ATS filter.

To anyone struggling right now -
Your rejection letter is not the final word.
Itâ€™s just a detour.

One â€œYESâ€ is enough to erase 100 â€œNOs.â€
One door can change your whole life.

And when that door opens -
Youâ€™ll look back and thank every single rejection that didnâ€™t work out.

Because rejections donâ€™t break you.
They build you.

ðŸ”¥ Remember this: You are not your rejections. You are your resilience.

The Real Reason People Quit -

Itâ€™s rarely just about money.
Itâ€™s about:

Feeling invisible in meetings.

Never hearing a â€˜thank you.â€™

Being treated like a resource instead of a person.

We think attrition is solved with better pay and perks.
But sometimes, itâ€™s solved by basic human decency.

Corporate has a silent bias.

The woman who dresses up, wears heels, red lipstick, and looks â€œpolishedâ€ - is called confident, ambitious, leadership material.

The woman who chooses comfort over contour - plain clothes, no makeup, no heels â€” is often overlooked. Sometimes even judged.

But think about itâ€¦
Why is confidence linked to lipstick?
Why is competence tied to high heels?
Why canâ€™t comfort and capability coexist?

Not every woman wants to â€œplay prettyâ€ just to be respected.
Some of us want to play real.

I donâ€™t want to spend hours in front of the mirror.
I donâ€™t want to wear lipstick to prove Iâ€™m confident.
I donâ€™t want to wear heels that hurt, just to look â€œpresentable.â€

I want to dress for myself.
To be comfortable.
To be taken seriously for my work - not my eyeliner.

And men - you face this too.
The tall guy in a suit and expensive watch is instantly seen as a leader.
The shorter man in a simple shirt is often underestimated, no matter how sharp his mind is.

Looks fade.
Trends fade.
But skills, grit, and character donâ€™t.

Workplaces need to value substance over style.
Because people come here to work - not to walk a runway.

Because hereâ€™s the truth:

No one remembers the shade of lipstick you wore to a meeting.

But they will remember the ideas you brought,
the problems you solved,
and the integrity you carried.

Red lipstick fades.
But skills, grit, and character - they donâ€™t.

You earn â‚¹1,00,000 a month.

But spend â‚¹60,000 on therapy, medicines, and stress relief.

Thatâ€™s not income.
Thatâ€™s recovery cost.

Choose wisely.

LinkedIn feed today:

One guy: â€œThrilled to announce my promotion!â€

Next guy: â€œThrilled to announce my layoff!â€

Another guy: â€œThrilled to announce my cat learned SQL.â€

Meanwhile me: Thrilled to announceâ€¦ nothing. Just scrolling, silently judging. 

At this point, LinkedIn isnâ€™t a professional network - itâ€™s a mix of Bigg Boss, Shark Tank, and Comedy Circus.

But hereâ€™s the bright side -
Not all wins are meant for the feed. Some wins are small, invisible, and deeply personal.
Like the fact you didnâ€™t give up today. Or that you opened your laptop even when you didnâ€™t feel like it. Or that youâ€™re still here, still trying.

Your journey is valid even if itâ€™s not â€œannouncement-worthy.â€

One day, your update will inspire someone whoâ€™s silently scrolling right now. ðŸŒ¸

So donâ€™t compare your chapter 1 to someone elseâ€™s chapter 20.

Keep moving, keep growing, and keep believing.

To all job seekers scrolling right now - 
Donâ€™t lose hope.

Behind the â€œthrilled to announceâ€ posts, everyone has their struggles too.

Keep applying, keep learning, and keep showing up.

Your announcement is loadingâ€¦ just wait for the right timing. â³ðŸŒŸ

Because your story is unfolding beautifully - even if today it looks like silence. âœ¨
Just saw a LinkedIn Influencer with 'Organic Growth' written in the profile with 65K+ followers claiming that he can help you in growing your platform, copying the posts from other influencers.

Jobseekers, this oneâ€™s for you.
 Every application, every interview, every follow-upâ€¦ the pressure is immense.
 And I know what you're thinking: Am I not good enough? 
 But let me tell you, this isnâ€™t about you or your skills. Itâ€™s about a broken system where 60% of applicants never hear back. 
 Your mental health is not worth sacrificing for a system that doesnâ€™t acknowledge your worth. 
 Please remember, taking care of yourself is the real priority. 
 Your dream job will come, but for now, breathe. ðŸŒ»
Looking for jobs on LinkedIn is like online dating: Full of promises, but in the end, youâ€™re just left ghosted.

LinkedIn scams be like: 'Congratulations, you've been selected for a role you didnâ€™t even apply for!'

Next time when I'll be reading some LinkedIn Influencer's story, I am starting from the last line.
If there's a link attached to it, it's most probably a fake one.
Saves me time!

Every time I poured my heart into 5-6 rounds of interviews and faced rejection, it felt like a punch in the gut. The sleepless nights, the endless preparation, all for nothing.

But looking back, I realize it wasnâ€™t nothing. It was the Universeâ€™s way of saying, â€œNot this one, something better is on the way.â€

Every single time, Iâ€™ve been shown why that rejection happened.

Doors I thought I wanted to walk through were shut, only to have the right ones swing open.

The kind that aligned with my growth, my values, and my happiness.

At first, it stung. It hurt deeply. But now, when things donâ€™t go as planned, I donâ€™t panic.

I donâ€™t question my worth. I sit back, breathe, and trust. The Universe knows.

I know there's another plan waiting. Something bigger, better, and just for me.

To anyone feeling the weight of rejection: trust that the closed doors are protecting you from something you canâ€™t see right now.

Your path is being cleared for something even more beautiful.

To everyone who's still looking for a job...

I see you. I feel you. 💔

Every rejection email feels like a punch in the gut, and every 'We'll get back to you' sounds more like 'You'll never hear from us.'

But I want you to know, you're not alone in this. 🌸

According to a study, 80% of jobseekers struggle with anxiety and self-doubt during their search. It's normal to feel lost, but it's not the end.

Take breaks, breathe, and remember, this doesn't define you. Your worth is not tied to an offer letter. 💥

Your mental health matters more than any job.

Sometimes, we forget that a companyâ€™s brand name doesnâ€™t define someoneâ€™s talent. Itâ€™s easy to get caught up in the 'big company = big talent' mindset, but that's not always the case.

Iâ€™ve had the privilege of working with people from smaller companies (lesser known) who blow me away with their skills and dedication. They donâ€™t need a fancy title or a famous brand behind them to prove their worth.

I've seen the other side tooâ€”people in top-tier companies feeling lost, overwhelmed, or stuck, even though the world sees them as 'successful'.

Letâ€™s stop attaching someoneâ€™s value to the company they work for. Freshers especially need to hear thisâ€”skills are what matter, not the size of the company behind them.

At the end of the day, happiness and growth donâ€™t come from a brand name, they come from doing what you love and constantly improving your craft.

So when I left a toxic work environment, I told my manager a simple thing and felt so good 😯

I just said-

'Hope your son gets a manager like you.
I hope that the manager behaves the same way as you did with me.
Thank you.'

Now tell me 1 thing-

She always said that she was a great manager.
Why will she get offended?

I just told her that I wish her son would get a manager like she was.

If you felt bad, then that means you were a bad manager and now you know it. � 80

If you feel good, then take it as a blessing for your son and you'll really want someone to treat your son/daughter in the same way.

She cannot be even angry with me else it'll prove that she was not a 'great' manager.

Muskan - 1
Manager - 0

Muskan -> Aura +100000000

(Fictional message unfortunately :(
)

Hope you all become the people that your sons/daughters will like to work under 🙏

There are a lot of bad people/things, bring a small change and break the chain :)
